metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ratilal Nathalal

facts.text: Hindu undivided family consisting of Ramjibhai, his son Ratilal Nathalal (respondent), Ramjibhai's wife Kamlawanti, Ratilal's wife Kantabai, and Ramjibhai's unmarried daughter Pushpa.
On July 27, 1933, Ramjibhai and Ratilal, the sole coparceners of the Hindu undivided family, executed a trust deed in respect of four items of house property belonging to the joint family.

Effect of trust deed: Income of settled property to be enjoyed by Ramjibhai during his lifetime; after his death, by respondent Ratilal alone, with right of residence for mother Kamlawanti in part of one house; after Ratilal's death, by his wife Kantabai and natural born sons in existence at death of survivor of Ramjibhai and Ratilal.
Express power of revocation of trust deed reserved to Ramjibhai by specific clause.
During Ramjibhai's lifetime, income from trust property assessed as joint family income under Section 16(1)(c) of Indian Income-tax Act, as addition to other admitted joint family income.

Section 16 of Indian Income-tax Act modified in 1939; clause (c) of sub-section (1) as amended deems income arising to any person by virtue of settlement or disposition (revocable or not) from assets remaining property of settlor to be income of settlor; income from revocable transfer deemed income of transferor; provisos define revocable and include settlor/dispoer broadly.
Income assessed in Ramjibhai's hands as Hindu undivided family income due to power of revocation reserved to him, treating settlor as Hindu undivided family.
After Ramjibhai's death, Income-tax authorities continued to assess income from trust properties in hands of respondent as family income for assessment years 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45, 1945-46.
Respondent objected that income was his individual income under settlement terms and Section 16(1)(c) had no application.
Assessee (respondent) appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal; Tribunal confirmed Income-tax authorities' view by order dated March 16, 1950.

At instance of respondent, Tribunal stated case to High Court of Bombay under Section 66(1); referred question: 'Whether in the circumstances of the case and on the true construction of the settlement deed, is the income from the trust property liable to be included in the income of the assessee Hindu undivided family?'

High Court held: Settlement by Ramjibhai and Ratilal as sole coparceners representing Hindu undivided family (settlor); but income received by Ratilal after Ramjibhai's death is his individual income, not joint family income.
Appeal to Supreme Court under Section 66A by Commissioner of Income-tax against High Court's decision on second point.

legal_issues.text: Whether, after Ramjibhai's death, the income from trust property in hands of Ratilal is liable to be included as income of the assessee Hindu undivided family under Section 16(1)(c) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Learned Attorney-General contends that by virtue of second proviso to Section 16(1)(c), Ratilal is a settlor; provision in trust deed for income to Ratilal after Ramjibhai's death is retransfer to settlor; thus last portion of Section 16(1)(c) applies, deeming income of Ratilal to be income of transferor (Hindu undivided family).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 16(1)(c) and provisos, Indian Income-tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: Income received by Ratilal after Ramjibhai's death is his individual income per trust deed; Section 16(1)(c) has no application; settlor was not Hindu undivided family but two individual members; in any case, no retransfer.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Terms of trust deed; Ramji Keshavji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay

court_reasoning.text: Fallacy in appellant's argument: Treats Ratilal as settlor per second proviso but family as settlor for last portion of Section 16(1)(c). Hindu undivided family is unit independent of coparceners; retransfer to Ratilal (individual) not to settlor (family); thus last portion of Section 16(1)(c) not attracted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hindu undivided family is a unit independent of and larger than the two coparceners.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly held settlement executed by Ramjibhai and Ratilal as coparceners representing family; income to Ratilal received in individual capacity, not on behalf of family; trust deed does not benefit joint family.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ratilal alienated property in one capacity (representing family) but receives benefit in different capacity (individual).

holdings.text: Income from trust property after Ramjibhai's death is individual income of Ratilal, not joint family income; Section 16(1)(c) last portion and provisos do not apply to deem it family income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramji Keshavji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Respondent relied on it for no retransfer of income; court finds unnecessary to express opinion.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs appeal, reference, and deeming provisions for settlement/transfer income.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax (Amendment) Act, 1939 (VII of 1939)
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced deeming provisions for revocable settlements and dispositions.

outcome.summary: Appeal by Commissioner dismissed; High Court decision affirmed that income from trust property is individual income of respondent Ratilal, not assessable as Hindu undivided family income under Section 16(1)(c).
outcome.relief_granted: Income not to be included in assessee Hindu undivided family income.

key_quotes.text: The fallacy of this argument consists in treating the respondent Ratilal as one out of two settlors for the purpose of the second proviso while treating the family as the settlor for the purpose of the last portion of clause (c) of Section 16(1).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning rejecting appellant's interpretation of Section 16(1)(c).

key_quotes.text: Hindu undivided family is a unit independent of and larger than the two coparceners and is not merely a collection of the individuals who acted on its behalf.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key observation distinguishing family as settlor from individual coparceners.

key_quotes.text: Ratilal alienated the property in one capacity and he receives the benefit under the trust deed in an altogether different capacity. Therefore it cannot be stated that this trust deed in any way benefits the joint family.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why income is individual, quoting High Court reasoning adopted.
